title: Folger Tech FT-5 adjustable Z endstop mounts

description.text:
I wasn't happy (like many people) with the z-stop mount that comes with the printer. i felt it was flimsy, easily out of alignment, and hard to accurately adjust. I played around with an inductive sensor, but had reliability issues, which is really bad for a z-stop.. So i decided to simplify.

After searching around, i couldn't find what I wanted, so I did what any sensible person does: roll my own :).

The three sets of parts are a z-stop mount for the z-endstop, a bracket to which a screw and some nuts are attached for adjustment, and a cap to make for a bigger target (optional, but I use it). Left and right versions are included (and marked with an "L" or "R").

For each side, you just need 2x M5 bolts and t-nuts for the top bracket, an M3 x 50mm or so bolt for the adjustable screw, one M3 nyloc, and one regular M3 nut. This will work with a stock hotend, and, if using a suitable longer adjustment screw, also with hotends that protrude further into the build area.

Update 3/18/2017: I switched my printer to a dual-z stop setup, so I also made a left-side version and included it here.

Printer:

FolgerTech Kossel 2020

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed in PLA.

Use pliers to squeeze a nyloc in the top hex recess, flip it over, thread a regular M3 nut on the longer adjustment screw of your choosing, and while applying pressure, screw the bolt through the bracket into the nylock. This will ensure everything is properly seated without any play.

Screw the cap on the bolt, try to make it square to the bolt.

Use longer M3 screws to mount the lower holder to the movable build plate, right where the FRU8LUU linear bearing is. My FT-5 had several leftover bolts that were suitable length.

After mounting the bottom bracket, screw the z-stop switch to the bracket using two m3 bolts and two nylock screws, add two M5 screws and nylocks (again, there were leftovers in my kit), position the switch "arm" over the cap on the adjustment screw, and fix in place.

comments.text: Just wanted to say thanks, great design and time saver. Probably the best of all the designs.I can't understand why they haven't fixed or used a better design. I just got mine last week.  Not sure why you would need two unless you were installing a Z max+ sensor for an auto Home.  If the bed is not level.
comments.author: LamboDad

comments.text: Thank you for the comment, much appreciated.
comments.author: LamboDad

comments.text: I see your rational, however having two Z stops, I am not sure how that will detect an out-of-alignment situation. I assume you are wiring them in series or parallel, if you are not connecting to the Z+ and Z- and if that is the case,  if one side triggers the sensor before the other I don't see how that is going to tell you or the RAMPS, that it is out of alignment, it is just going to tell you (depending on series or parallel) a "Z value" and depending on which one is triggered first (lower or higher) the controller is just going to use that as your Z value, not that they don't match (unless I am not following your logic)
comments.author: evandepol

comments.text: No, they are rewired to work independently (using a well known mod involving the z max endstop Connector to act as the homing stop for the second (left most) z axis), and each side homes simultaneously but stops indepdently.

comments.text: Oh!  I'll have to look that Mod up unless you have a link to share :) thanks

title: Enhanced MP Select Mini Fan Shroud

description.text:
I realized that my MP Select Mini's prints were having some print warping issues due to the uneven cooling the stock fan shroud provided. I found Kenny_boy's design and really liked it, but I touched on a few things.

1) The hole pattern was corrected for the stock fan.
2) A small gap on each side of the fan ring let some air through, I closed that gap which should help make the airflow more uniform.
3) I used meshmixer to add manual supports to the only two points that needed support. The model as is needs no additional support material when printing.

Overall, I'm having fantastic part cooling using this shroud and I wanted to share the improvements I made.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

comments.text: I printed this with the stock shroud, installed it and printed again to compare the difference in print quality -- I thought this would improve the 'back' of the prints, but it actually made it worse. description.text:
This is basically a remix of the SAMLA Hanga for storing filament in an IKEA SAMLA box.
The original design was all one piece and required a lot of support. With my settings in Cura the original took 9.5m and time of 1:50. Plus there was all that support material to clean up and mar the surface.

So I redesigned this in 2 pieces so that I could print it WITHOUT any support while still maintaining the strength and ease of install.

So print the Bottom 1/2 and top 1/2 twice laying them flat on the bed with NO Supports, then assemble as shown. The clip on part of the Hanga ensures that the pieces will stay in place without any gluing but you can glue if needed.

Sketchup files included if needed.

Geeetech Full Metal Aluminum

20%

title: KNRLR - a tool for making knurled bolts which are actually spiky

description.text:
This nice thing attaches to your Dremel and lets you make your own M8 knurled bolts for your extruder. Technically speaking it's a "spiked" bolt, not a knurled one, but it's close enough. :) And yes, the name is supercheesy, but I like it anyway.
I made this because the standard Ultimaker knurled bolt doesn't fit the extruder I'm currently designing. 
It's modelled in 3dsmax, so no openscad files, sorry :( If anybody wants to make a parametric version be my guest.

Print all the parts. I sliced mine with Cura, 0.2 layers, 25% infill. You'll need:
2x M3x8 screws
1x M3x20 or longer screw
1x M8 nut (NOT a locking nut) To prepare:
  • Use two M3x8 screws to attach part B to part A.
  • Use one M3x20 screw and attach the Dremel mount to part B. (do not overtighten to ensure a smooth motion of the mount)
  • Remove the rubber cap from the tip of your Dremel 300(should work with other Dremels too).
  • Gently screw on the hexagonal part to the top of the Dremel tool.
  • Attach a thin cutting disc to the Dremel.(I sincerely recommend original Dremel discs, the Chinese knockoffs tend to shatter and get spent to quickly so you have an inconsistent cutting radius, also due to that they produce a cloud of nasty metal dust - very bad to inhale).
  • Place a M8 bolt you intend to cut through the round hole on part A
  • Screw in the 17 tooth gear to the bolt, being careful that the bottom layer you printed is turned toward the tip of the bolt. (That's for a better fit to part A, cause the first layers tend to be a bit wider than the rest of the part).
  • Place the gear in its slot on part A and screw the bolt to the correct position for cutting.
  • Screw on the M8 nut to secure the gear in position.
    • To cut:
  • Turn on the Dremel to max speed.
  • Holding the Dremel in one hand, use your other hand to push the bolt towards the cutting disc (it's good to keep your thumb on the M8 nut, to secure the bolt in place).
  • Make a quick precise cut.
  • Pull it away from the disc and rotate the bolt one tooth in your preferred direction to prepare for a new cut.
    • Repeat until done. Easy ain't it? In reality it's done in a minute but I wanted to leave detailed instructions so nobody misses something or hurts himself (please use hand/eye protection). It makes bolts which grip like the devil. Haven't tested them though because I'm still working on my extruder. Hopefully it will be done soon.

Here

This will fit any of the Lulzbot extruders, for all the AO-10x variants, the Taz variants 1-6, and the Lulzbot Mini. it should also fit most other Greg/Wade style extruders

Edit: If your existing idler bolt does NOT have threads all the way up, you may need to replace it with a new 25mm long M3 Cap head bolt. Depending on your luck with edge curling, I added helper disks to all the small edges (My MakerBot 2X Experimental Printer has been relabeled Tempermental)  
1/8" holes were created to use the screws I pulled from the HP 2.5" sas drive assembly.

This thing is a valve that uses a bearing (or marble) as valve.
Inspiration: http://www.wot.utwente.nl/publications/demo-knikkerpomp/demoknikkerpomp-v5.pdf

1) Enter correct dimensions for diameter of tube, bearing size etc.
2) Print
3) Heat up bearing in a fire and press it just a little in the hole in the bottom part. This helps to create a more smooth surface so the bearing seals the hole better.
4) Put bearing in and glue together (I used PVC glue for ABS). Notes:
  • For a pump, the inner valve should fit smoothly in the outer valve. You can use a rubber ring to seal it off if necessary.
    • I used:
  • 5/8" PVC tube for inner tube
  • 3/4" PVC tube for outer tube
  • two 7.144 mm bearing ball
  • PVC glue

title: Parametric universal spool holder remix using R8-2RS bearigs

description.text:
This is a remix version of rowokii's Parametric universal spool holder http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:767317 .

It uses more common (in the U.S.) fractional hardware (1/2" rod). The bearings used are R8-2RS 1-1/8" OD x 1/2" ID.

I had first intended to get some 608 bearings and buy an 8 mm threaded rod. I remembered I had these bearings on hand from another project, so I decided to remix the spool holder to fit them.

The added benefit was that I was able to purchase the threaded rod at the local hardware store instead of having to wait for something to come in the mail.

Another added benefit is that 1/2" rod is thicker (12.7 mm) and therefore stronger than 8 mm rod. You would be able to build a longer spool holder that could support many spools.

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=767317

I printed these a little overkill with 3 perimeters and 50% infill, you could easily get away with 2 perimeters and 20% infill.

0.2 mm layer height.

It's important you have a machine with a filament fan as there's a decent gap to bridge 28.6mm (1-1/8").
If your printer doesn't have these bridging abilities you may need to print it with support.

These printed fine with no raft on an unheated bed covered with painter's tape.

description.text:
I'm going to update this with a video walk though once I have time.

I wanted to make night light panels with lithophanes, and needed a simple way to mount them.

I use the cheap LED night lights from wal-mart. Comes in a 4 pack for $6. The clear panel just slides off, and the lithophane panel slides right on.

https://www.walmart.com/ip/Meridian-Great-Value-4-Pack-LED-Automatic-Night-Light/26135731

This is how I make them:

Create a lithophane from the 3DRocks Website (http://3dp.rocks/lithophane/)
Parameters:
3mm or 4mm maximum thickness
.80 minimum thickness
5 Vectors/Pixel for higher quality
80mm size (for portraits this sets max height. 80mm is perfect for a night light)
Choose "Positive Image" so the dark parts are thickest.
For model type, choose outside curve.

Now save that STL.

Open Meshmixer and import your lithophane.
Then Import (Append) the night light attachment
Choose Edit -> Transform and move it so it "intersects" with the night light.
With Object Viewer open, select both STLs then choose combine.
Then choose make solid.
Change Solid Accuracy and Mesh Density to both 450 and then update/apply to make the lithophane quality back to normal. This may take a while depending on CPU power.
Save the new STL.

Print at .12 layer height, 30mm to 60mm/sec depending on your machine's capabilities. 1 outline, 100% fill. May need a brim if you have bed adhesion issues. I print a 10 line brim, with 0.10mm separation distance from the part so it peels off very easily.

Friends and family absolutely LOVE these, and at less than $2 for the night light, a couple meters of filament and about 2 hours average for the print it's a cheap and fast gift!

title: Adjustable Nintendo Switch Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
After making the original stand, the obvious evolution of that idea was to make an adjustable and portable version. This stand features four different angle positions, making comfortable play easy enough regardless of the situation. It also collapses down to a somewhat smaller profile.

NOTE: This design is a little more complex and as such, requires some hardware in order to be used. This stand requires four M3 screws. (14 - 16mm)

Possible issues: I was able to get it to a profile that would fit in my Legend of Zelda Switch case, but the shelf is proving to be a problem for now. Due to the nature of thin 3d prints, PLA printed stands may not be robust enough to survive rough handling.

  • Tinker Gryphon Designs

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Ultimately, it is up to you how you wish to print the stand portion. I printed it standing upright with supports and a brim at about a 65 degree angle to achieve a thicker cross-section of layers. You may choose to pursue a different route.

Assembly

Putting the stand together is very straight forward. Refer to the photos for any clarification.

I recommend threading the screws all the way into the base and the supports prior to assembly. Depending on your print, it could be difficult to feed the screws in. The holes on the stand backrest are oversized so they shouldn't grab the screw much when swiveling the hinges.

title: Monoprice Maker Select Plus LED Clips

description.text:
This was so that the camera had better light but could be powered when the OCTOPI was on. Very simple only took about 2hrs for me.

The base of the opening for the clip is exactly the width of the frame, but it tapers to a smaller width the closer you get to the tips.

UPDATED: 3/16/17
I noticed a little give from the adhesive one the strips.. so I added new clips. that will hold the strips in place. Nice snug fit!
https://youtu.be/WmGBaHgJat4

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15%

Notes:

If you print this with a raft it will warp.....or at least mine did.

Printed:
XT:245
BD:70
PETG
FAN:100

Requirements
3528smd LEDs (5V power supply)
USB Cable
Soldering Iron
Solder Per strip, I used about 13 LED per side(3) and cut right in the middle of the copper pads. Removed the resin covering the pads and soldered wires about 3-4inches long. Removed the 3M sticky cover and placed them on the the printed clips. Clip them on and enjoy.

You will need a basic knowledge of soldering but can easily get by with little to no knowledge. How to Do It: Basic Soldering:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BLfXXRfRIzY
I used PETG and a simple 5V LED strip from amazon that came prewired (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B015R87GQK/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1)

Case made to hold the typical 48 SMD LED panels you find all over Amazon & Ebay that have all of the funky car dome light connectors. I would probably recommend when wiring the panel to possibly utilize a resistor to knock down the brightness & the temperature. A potentiometer even.

UPDATE: As for utilizing a resistor, sweet spot seems to be between 30Ω & 40Ω. The LED doesn't get hot at all, slightly warm to the touch after 15 minutes of use. 40Ω and higher, the LED stays cool & still puts off decent light if you keep the LED closer to the bed.

title: TEVO Black Widow Fanduct + BLT Mount + Two 40x20 Fan + Hot air pipe

description.text:
Fan Duct + Two cooling fan + BLTouch mount + Hot air pipe for TEVO Black Widow

When developing, I tried to combine the maximum of useful improvements in one model taking up a minimal place and having a small weight.
It has :

  • Closed central duct which allows using a standard fan to prevent cooling heater.
  • Pipe for two 20 mm cooling fans (10mm fans can also be used).
  • Mount the BLT sensor located more close to the nozzle.
  • Removable air pipe to retract hot air from the working area.

Screws to mount:
2pc M4x15mm (for central mount)
2pc M4x15mm (for Left and Right duct)
4pc M3x25mm (for center fan, use standard TEVO screw)
2pc M2x10mm + M2 nuts (for BLT sensor or use use standard screw)
8pc M3x20mm (for two cooling fans)
*** If you have 40x10mm fan use M3x10mm screw)

BLTouch offsets:
X= 26mm
Y= -19mm
Z= -1.5 (May be little bit different (-1.4 or -1.6), you need to do a calibration Z axis)

Printer:

Tevo Black Widow

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30% +

Notes:

For optimal printing results, you can use the placement of parts as indicated on my photo.

Setting up support:
Support Resolution: 1.0mm
Support Infill: 20%
Upper and Lower Separation: 0mm

Print settings:
Material: ABS, Hotend: 250C, Bed: 105C, Print Speed: 35mm/s
Printing time 6:00 hours

author: 5490robert

description.text:
Problem 1: You're off to bed when you realize you're all out of dish detergent, and not a clean table setting in the house for breakfast.

Problem 2: You've invited Magneto to your brunch party, but you're a little worried he might lose his temper.

Solution: Press print, and by morning you have a clean set of non-magnetic tableware (sterilized at 220 degrees Celsius).

Later on, you "accidentally" drop your silverware at a fine restaurant. As the waiter rushes over with a clean set, you deftly swing your hands in the air and... swish-swoosh-swish... "Don't bother, my good man, I have my own." Ladies swoon.

https://youtu.be/-j6bEiTJrlg

Prints fine without raft, brim, supports, or infill. For a cool trick, set your slicer to pause at 15mm, then swap in a different color filament.

Note to Small Printer Folk: Through the magic of the hypotenuse, rotating a single item 45 degrees on your print bed allows you to print a 170mm item on a 126mm x 126mm bed!

Note to Children of School-going Years: If you bring this to school you will likely be expelled. Fair warning!

Note to Lawsuit-happy Americans: If you manage to cut yourself or anyone else with this, you were trying REALLY HARD and thus it was YER OWN DURNED FAULT.

And yes, I did just discover markdown, so I'm sure for the next several days everything I post will have annoying and random formatting.

title: FLEXATX Power Supply Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a project case for a FlexATX power supply. I have a ton of them harvested from dead servers (common power supply in small 1RU servers) and needed a way to mount one up to power some LED lighting.

The case is in 3 parts, I call the AC side (AC Plug), center section and DC Side. Has holes for a power switch, second fan and the output leads. There is enough room for a small amount of electronics in the DC side if you wanted to (maybe a constant current circuit for instance.)

I never actually bothered to print the center section. The fit is pretty snug, with only a tolerance of about .25mm here and there. The center section is deliberately undersized about .5mm lengthwise (rather have a little slop than too tight.)

If you use the second fan, mount it first and reach through the blades to mount the DC side to the power supply.

print_settings.Notes:: MIGHT NOT

description.text:
IMPORTANT NOTE :- THIS WAS DESIGNED FOR MY OWN USE AND I POSTED IT HERE FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES. I'LL NOT BE RESPONSIBLE FOR ANY DAMAGES TO YOUR SWITCH OR ANYTHING THAT HAPPENS DUE TO THE USE OF THE CASE.

This is a case I designed for the Nintendo Switch, I had trouble finding a proper pouch for the Switch locally, so I designed this case to protect so I can chuck it into any other bag. This should be used as a case on it's own unless you feel very confident with the strength of joining the parts together.

WARNING : The COVER CAP DOES NOT LOCK! And the weight of the Switch WILL push it open if turned upside down!

NOTE :- Please watch the video to identify the contact points where you need to stick the foam padding on to prevent the screen from rubbing on the case when inserting the Switch

In case you're wondering, the case shown was printing using PETG.

Printer Brand:

Up!

Printer:

Up Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25MM

Infill:

25%

Notes:

2 pieces of the SHAFT is needed to form the case. Recommend that you first print the cap and A shaft to see if your printer tolerance will allow for the 0.1MM gap on the cap to fit over the shaft properly before you continue.

Rotate the parts so that they print vertically and require minimum support material. Supports are mainly used for the rounded edges on the caps.

If you want REALLY tight connections that MIGHT NOT need any sort of adhesives to finish up, you can try using the 0MM gap connector parts that will result in a VERY tight fit between the parts but depending on your printer accuracy, might not even join together!

Demo video and assembly instructions. Watch The Video

Please watch the video on assembly instructions and other information.

PLEASE REMEMBER TO SECURE ALL THE CONNECTORS so the case doesn't disassemble itself!

Gscheiduino (Meaning: Arduino done intelligently) is a nice Arduino variant offered by a small german electronics outfit. http://www.ehajo.de/baus%C3%A4tze/bedrahtete-baus%C3%A4tze/gscheiduino-arduino%E2%84%A2genuino%E2%84%A2-clon.html
Since unfortunately the pcb does not exactly match the Arduino specs, I did have to tinker Esquilos design again :-)

remixed_from.author: willie42
remixed_from.title: Crossfire Shortend Vibration Dampening Battery Tray for Gimbal

description.text:
As the videos of my rollei410 were to bad (extreme compression-artefacts) I tried another cam, the RunCam2.

Because of the different form of the cam-body I had to change the length of the arms to have the lens in the center, and because of the longer gimbal arms, it makes sense to use the shortened battery-tray.
With one motor on the right side, I added counter weight on the left (tin coins).

UPDATES

Update: I added a short battery-tray for mounting the gimbal at a lower level. More info: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2188215

Update2: Here is a little video. There are still some vibrations - besides a few gusts ;) . I think I will have to use harder damping balls.

https://youtu.be/h5YS4Z0wpEw

Update3: I added a shorter version of gimbal_arm1. This makes it possible to run the system without counter-weights - as a consequence the total weight is reduced, but I had to move the lens out of the center.
This and the use of harder dampening balls makes the trembling/shaking that I had in the previous footage disappear:
https://youtu.be/TCtnjOtO6rI

description.text: Imes Icore 350i CAD-CAM drill holder

I put too much junk in my closet and the shelving collapsed. The brackets holding the shelf to the wall shattered. In an effort to save $5.99 plus shipping I figured I'd make one myself

In the interest of structural integrity, you should probably print with 100% infill. However, it should be noted that a printed part won't be as strong as a factory made piece. Don't actually use this bracket if you plan on having it support a lot of weight as I haven't actually tested how durable this print is.
I measured the bracket's parts and put it together in freeCAD

description.text:
Nouvelle tête basée sur la base de celle développée par dragon-shark que vous trouverez ici (encore merci pour cette super version initiale qui améliore considérablement le refroidissement):

https://www.lesimprimantes3d.fr/forum/topic/5064-am%C3%A9lioration-t%C3%AAte-dimpression/

La modification apportée concerne la fixation au roulements. J'ai mis les mêmes empreintes que celles utilisées sur la tête d'origine car après avoir démonté plusieurs fois la version initiale, elle avait tendance à ne pas bien se fixer sur les roulements et à glisser.

Deux versions: Avec ou sans le support pour démarrer une chaîne passe câble intégrés à la tête.

La suite de la chaîne:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1872842

Une autre tête semble également convenir à pas mal d'utilisateurs de Discoeasy 200:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2163320

Personnellement je préfère la fixation des courroies de Dragon-Shark, et n'ai pas de problèmes avec le switch de fin de course X; raison pour laquelle je suis parti sur cette base.

A vous de faire votre choix ou de les modifier (j'ai mis les fichiers STEP de ma tête)

title: Customizable Wire Spool Holder Box / Dispenser

description.text:
A customizable box with spools for wires, and doors/lids with holes for dispensing the wires. Very convenient for electronics hobbyists.

You can customize everything from the number of spools and rows, to the diameter of the wires and the sizes of the spools etc.

Could also be customized to hold different kinds of wires or chains or anything that fits on a spool and needs dispensing.

Parts print without support. The two halves of the spools benefit from some glue to keep them together.

If you have any questions or comments please leave me a message.

comments.text: Had a problem with the spool top - will not fit into the bottom. Glued it directly, but now it will not fit into the dispenser lol. Maybe check the download files, could be my printer settings though.
comments.author: amasters

comments.text: Please change the tolerance settings in the customizer if you are having trouble fitting the parts together. Look under the section printing-tolerances. If you having issues understanding them please let me know and I'll help you out.
comments.author: amasters

comments.text: Your download files are the problem. If I use the customizer with default tolerances they fit together without a problem. Suggest you fix the files so someone else does not waste their time downloading the files and then discovering they do not fit together. If you check the files you get when you download them directly rather than using the customizer, you will find the problem. The diameter of the projection on the 'top' is identical to the od of the 'bottom' projection. There is no way these will fit together.
comments.author: STTrife

comments.text: Thanks for reporting, I have replaced the spoolTop to the one that is generated with the default settings. I must have made a mistake when generating some standard STL files. Hope you got a working spoolholder now. If you have any comments or suggestions for improvement let me know.
comments.author: amasters

comments.text: Thanks this will be most helpful for that little bit of filament left on the spool I save for my 3D Pen
comments.author: Skelch

comments.text: You're welcome, for that purpose I suggest you make the inside (inner diameter), and the outside diameter of the spools larger or you'll be bending the filament too much when you roll it up on the spool. You can use the customizer for that, look at the spool size and fine tune settings. Good luck!

description.text: To get you started turning puny thingiverse things into Beefy Beefcakes, here's a ready to use meshmixer part and OpenSCAD module for quick and easy Beefy Arms! EDIT: added an .stl for additional Beefification EDIT: by the way, these arms were generated with the excellent MakeHuman, an open source anatomically accurate human character generator. It's pretty awesome and also generates a working rig that you can load up in blender to pose. I also used the Blender to OpenSCAD exporter to generate the .scad module #beefyarms

to add the meshmixer part to your library put it in your /Documents/Meshmixer/Library/Default folder to use the beefy_arm.scad, put the file in your /Documents/OpenSCAD/libraries/ folder and then in a new file type use <beefy_arm.scad> beefy_arm();

description.text:
Quick attach multicopter leg, for 20mm wide and 4mm thick arms (taking into account ESC/motor wires on top, and a 3rd slot for sponge legs, like Machine X220 Wizard).
Uses nylon cable ties (max 3mm wide) to attach leg above and below - THIS IS A TEMPORARY leg, not made to be permanent, I designed this to be able to quickly attach a GoPro/ChinPro BELOW my X220, to do some vertical photography / search and rescue, as I'd lost another quad in an area with many boulders and bushes, and with these legs I can hold the ChinPro below my other quad, looking down, to hopefully later revise the footage and maybe see my lost quad!

author: sabharish

description.text:
Low-cost Handheld Microtome

This is a microtome which is typically used for shaving very thin lays of a specimen for microscopy in pathology and similar fields. I made two different versions of microtomes. One has a place to put a washer if you so feel like it. Another doesn't. The plug is an optional print as it is not 100% required but I included it just in case someone wanted to have something with more surface area pushing on the specimen.

All of the required material that you will need for this build will be located in the "post-printing" section. Also, I recommend that you print the top so the wide part is on the print bed. This is to ensure a very flat surface for the razor.

Materials:
  • 1 - M11 washer (24.0 mm outer diameter(OD))
  • 1- M10-32x40(The more threads the better)
  • 1-M10-32 nut
  • 60mm of 1/2 inch OD Aluminum tube(.444" inner diameter)
  • 25mm of 3/8 inch OD Aluminum rod(.375" OD)
  • Super glue
  • Sand paper

Instructions:

  1. Print all parts that you need
  2. Finish print if need be.(Sand anything that is rough)
  3. Cut tube and rod to size.
  4. Super glue or press-fit nut and bolt.
  5. Super glue or press-fit tube and washer.
  6. Prepare specimen with normal procedure
  7. Cut very thin lays by adjusting the height of specimen relative to the cutting surface.

description.text: Created this from two thingiverse objects because I wanted to test how the duct would affect the prints.

It's a simple print.
I printed with Cura. Layer height 0.25
Fill 20%

comments.text: so, how does it affect the print quality? From a glance at your picture, I'd say it needs a bit more cooling or lower temp+speed. There is a rule of thumb with EDFs (basically a very large powerful version of the computer fan) that the exit area should be not less than 75% of the intake area to get maximum thrust. In this case you will get a severely reduced airflow, as the exit is so very small.. Does the fan make a different sound too? If you want air at a higher pressure/speed you'd better go with a radial fan.
comments.author: JelleBoomstra

comments.text: You are correct the fan makes more noise now, because like you say the opening is not big enough. There is also more of a back flow from the fan now. The problem with putting a bigger fan there is that since this is the printrbot simple the head will hang lower when it's extended.

title: Monolith Fume Extractor
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a simple, very useful, solder fume extractor. Just place it upright or on its side near where you are soldering to keeps the fumes out of your face.

Just print, solder the fan leads to the battery case (after feeding them through the hole in the bottom of the extractor) then shove the wires into the cavity at the bottom of the fan holder and press the fan in. No need to glue the fan, it is a press fit.

Then glue the fan holder to the top of the battery case taking care not to get glue on the battery door. I used Goop adhesive, epoxy would also work well.

That's it. Put some batteries in it and enjoy not having solder fumes waft up in your face.

Requires;
One 60mm x 60mm x 15mm, 5V fan.
One four cell AA battery holder with switch.

Here are four fans at Mouser;
http://www.mouser.com/Thermal-Management/Fans-Blowers/Fans/DC-Fans/_/N-dwatbZscv7?P=1z0wulw&Keyword=60x60+fan&FS=True

I recommend the slowest, lowest amp draw one for longest battery life and quietest operation. It takes very little airflow to be effective so using a stronger fan is a waste.

You can get a battery holder from Pololu;
http://www.mouser.com/Thermal-Management/Fans-Blowers/Fans/DC-Fans/_/N-dwatbZscv7?P=1z0wulw&Keyword=60x60+fan&FS=True

title: Car holder for iPhone 5/5s/SE w. cover

description.text:
This is car-holder for an iPhone 5/5s/SE that is being used with a protective cover. Typically such covers increase the volume of the phone, and hence the internal space is bigger than that of a "naked" phone to accommodate for that.

The holder is intended to be attached to a bracket in the car using M2.5 screws.
There are numerous holes at the back to generalize the design and make it possible to attach it to all sorts of brackets. The holes have cavities for the screws' heads so that they won't interfere with the phone's insertion or removal.

There is a cut at the front and bottom to allow easy access to the iphone's home button and power inlet.

Also, the top-left corner is removed using a large round cut. This allows access to the volume buttons on the left side of the phone, as well as easier insertion and removal of the phone from the holder.

I hope you enjoy it and find it useful.

Removal of support

Depending on the printing parameters, removal of the support may be needed. This includes passing a round object at each hole (I used a thin cross screwdriver) as well as cleaning the cavities for the screws' heads.

I looked over the net for the dimensions of the iPhone. Based on that I created a set of parameters for the holder. Those parameters are editable in the .SCAD file, and therefore the design can be adapted.

Initially I created a "rounded cube" module, and used that to create the body of the holder and remove the internal housing using the "difference" operation. Following that I created the back extrusion with the holes, cut the top-left corner and the bottom and front cuts for the home button, power inlet and speakers.

comments.text: Nice project! I hope to see more interesting brackets and phone accessories coming soon! (Perhaps you could name the case you have on your phone/model and take a photo to show tolerance?)

This is an attachment for the diamond hotend. Print it to use it with your Rostock.

This is specifically designed to work with the rostock Jaws and joints, without the need of modification to any of the existing parts of the rostock.

The design is such that the end effector does not need to be printed again. The attachment sits on top of it and can be screwed from the bottom.

If the tower holes are small for M3 Bolts then i would suggest to use M2x15 bolt on each tower.

Put the bolt head on top of the opening, hold it with a nose pliers, heat the bolt with a soldering iron and push it inside the tower. Then you can put nuts and washers.

New version is up. Stronger now. Goes on the sides now, instead of like 1/3rd of the way in.

--UPDATE--
Needs more support. The heat from the router causes the PLA to warp, making it loose grip on the router. I think that just making the "fingers" longer would be enough, though I may just add a spine from the hole to the ends. We'll see.
Things to do:
-Add support
-Design different version where you can easily access all ports, and where the WPS button doesn't accidentally get pushed.

--Original Post--
A simple way to hang your modem under your desk (or whatever you want)
The hole has a 5mm diameter. You can zip-tie it to something like a support bar, or some of those adhesive clips.

To attach:
Put one end onto the back, then slide the other over the curved edge of the modem.
I printed in PLA, it flexed enough to work that way, so you don't have to disconnect anything if you needed to read the label, or anything.

Yes

20%

With 20& infill, I don't know yet if the heat from the router will be enough to deform the print, as I've only just started using them.
I used 5 layers for the top and bottom (1mm), with two walls (.8mm).

I had been having trouble finding the perfect design bag clamp/clip to keep my corn-chips fresh. I first tried Marrrs design (Thing 1987727) but I found it to short and also it was difficult to slide the bag onto the clamp/clip.

Next I tried Jinja design (Thing 30664) and found it to be a great clamp/clip except his longest design was 120 mm long and I needed a longer one.

I then edited the design to make it about 60 mm longer. Now I have a easy to use bag clamp/clip that fits my corn chips nicely.

My life has been saved, as I will never have to eat stale Nachos again!

You can watch my video of the bag clips on YouTube. https://youtu.be/hg-MYaZC5R0

title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2.1 E3D Titan Aero Upgrade

description.text:
Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2.1 E3D Titan Aero Upgrade.

Upgrade your Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2.1 to use E3D's Titan Aero!

Use the complete range of E3D Heater Blocks & Nozzles | http://e3d-online.com/

I have also added in a few modifications to remove the dodgy belt-springs.

Refer to the Instructional_Images_Part_1/2.zip files for build and assembly guidance.

E3D Shopping List.

1 x E3D 12v Titan Aero.
1 x 12V 50x50x15 Blower Fan.
1 x E3D Thermistor Cartridge.

Print with your favourite thermoplastic | http://e3d-online.com/All-Filament

Additional Parts Shopping List

(eBay Affiliate Links)

A Selection of assorted Metric Socket Cap Screws (2 x M4 30mm, 2 x M4 20mm).
A Selection of assorted Metric Square Nuts (2 x M4).
A selection of assorted Metric Hex Half Nuts (2 x M4).
A Selection of assorted serated washers.
A Selection of assorted Nylon spacers (3 x M3 3mm).
A Selection of assorted Cable Ties.
A Selection of assorted Heatshrink.
A Selection of assorted Heatshrink.

I highly recommend updating the Melzi board to something which can fit on full-featured Marlin, features like autoleveling will make a huge improvement to your experience. Something like a RAMPS, RUMBA, Duet, RAMBO. Refer to the RepRap Wiki for a list.

Please help support my work here on Thingiverse and on Instructables by using the following affiliate links when making purchases. Thanks :)

eBay.com | eBay.co.uk | eBay.fr | Amazon.co.uk

E3D's BigBox

Yes

}

description.text:
I didn't like the look of the curved back section on the original piece so I redrew it from scratch with a solid rectangle. This also allows it to be printed horizontally :-)

With support on, this wall will print out in one piece. However....
The sharp-eyed amongst you will know that I usually put a few 28mm figures in for scaling purposes. The reason I haven't here is that the model is a 60% medium res prototype, and I'm finding that the concrete/aggregate wall filling is making the file a bit of a memory-buster. As I was quite pleased with the way the prototype turned out, I published it 'as is'. I'll add a new photo when I've persuaded my computer to make an effort! (Or chop the file in two if it continues to sulk)

title: Claystruder 1.5
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an evolution of the Claystruder 1.1 for Rapman.
Simpler, more modular. It does not yet feature a mount for a solenoid valve, maybe I add that in the future.

I made some improvements to the system since the Claystruder 1.1 version I posted on Thingiverse. The main one being the decoupling of the nozzle (a polyprop tapered tip) and the syringe. This simple change solves some issues with swapping syringes on long prints. If you have the nozzle attached to the syringe directly, like on the Frostruder, each time you want to swap a syringe you also remove and refit the nozzle with it and its very hard to get that syringe+nozzle back in the exact same spot again. Your nozzle is also never straight so even a slight rotation can put it a millimeter off. So if you continue your print (on Rapman its fairly easy top pause and restart a print) it will continue in a different spot. The solution is easy, make sure your nozzle stays in its place on the print head carriage when you remove the syringe. I use a small luer-lock male-female extension bit (http://www.dosieren.de/en/shop/products/cat/luer-lock-adapters/pr/luer-lock-special-model.html) that is glued in the printhead (a simple mount). The nozzle is fixed to one end and the syringe screws in the back. This feature should be part of any paste extruder that uses syringes since it solves a lot of trouble with multi-syringe prints. There is also a set of windows in the barrel holder that allow you to guard the level better. For this extruder I also designed a syringe adapter head that can be easily twisted on syringes and can withstand (depending on print quality) pressure up to 6 bar by adding bolts and washers as reinforcement. This file can be found on thingiverse here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:21074 This info was also posted at Unfold~fab: http://unfoldfab.blogspot.com/2012/04/road-to-better-paste-extrusion-episode.html

print_settings.Notes:: The only part that may need supports is the dodecahedron part. For all of them, you may want to print out a single test piece to check not only whether or not you need supports on your printer, but also to test the fit of the material you are using. If too loose or tight, a slight scale adjustment could improve things.

description.text:
This is a set of connectors that can be used with 1/4" wood dowel (or other 1/4" round material) to assemble the five platonic solids. These are the tetrahedorn, cube, octahedron, dodecahedron, icosahedron.

The wood pieces for each polyhedra need to be cut to the exact same lengths. For my build, I cut a bunch of 6" lengths of the wood dowel and assembled the 5 polyhedra shown in the photos.

I tapered the holes that the wood dowels go into and adjusted the interior diameter dimension to ensure a tight (interference) fit so the shapes would not fall apart. You may need to either sand down the wood ends some or use a drop of glue, depending on the exact diameter of the edge stock you end up using. For me, assembly required putting all the wood pieces in a tiny bit into each of the holes and then progressively pressing connectors together until all of the wood pieces bottomed out in the holes of the connector. This resulted in a tight fit requiring no glue.

Listed below are the number of connectors you would need for each shape:

Tetrahedron - 4
Octahedron - 6
Cube - 8
Icosahedron - 12
Dodecahedron - 20

Depending on your printer quality, you can try printing all the connectors for a shape at once, on you may need to print one at a time. That's for you to figure out. Irecommmend printing one of each polyhedra connector out first to test the hole size for your needs and scale up or down slightly if needed

If you like this "thing", also check out my other related things, including a fully customizable version of the polyhedral connectors (with slightly different base geometry) I made with OpenSCAD that can have the internal and external diameters adjusted along with lengths and tolerance. It can be found here:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2125889

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The only part that may need supports is the dodecahedron part. For all of them, you may want to print out a single test piece to check not only whether or not you need supports on your printer, but also to test the fit of the material you are using. If too loose or tight, a slight scale adjustment could improve things.

description.text:
The channels on my greenhouse are a little different to those the original supported, so I remixed it.

I've made 2 versions, one with the retainer in line with the hanger, and one at 90 degrees to the hanger so that a hanger can support a load in different directions as required.

These are smaller than the original as I plan to use them for running support strings.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Yes

Resolution:

5%

After working with FreeCAD for some time now I figured I should post some basic pattern objects I've been using. If you have never tried FreeCAD, it is a free and opensource CAD software available for Linux, Windows, and Mac. You can find it here: http://sourceforge.net/. It is still in development, but the most recent versions 0.13 and 0.12 have made the GUI usable and getting ever closer to a very nice opensource CAD software. I'm posting the .stl and the freeCAD files, .fcstd.
There are only a few objects here now but I'll be posting things here as I continue. If you post any objects with FreeCAD, please tag it with FreeCAD so others can find them easily.
